results.title: Lily Aime Moi = Lily, Love Me
results.brief_description:
Francois, a journalist, is ordered to write an article on the life of a working class man. This is how he meets Claude who has just been abandoned by his wife, Lily. Francois decide to put his job on the side and attempts to help Claude mend his relationship with Lily. The film follows for three days the adventures of two men who were never meant to meet while brushing a warm and ironic portrait of friendships, complicity and relationships.

Credits: Producer, Michel Seydoux ; director, Maurice Dugowson ; writer, Michel Vianey ; photography, Andre Diot ; music, Edgardo Canton.
Cast: Rufus, Jean-Michel Folon, Patrick Dewaere, Zouzou, Roland Dubillard, Juliette Creco, Andreas Voutsinas, Tatiana Moukhine, Roger Blin, Miou-Miou, Henry Jaglom.

results.title: Lilija Duks: weaver
results.creator_credit: Nina Syme, Terry McMahon and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
Lilija Duks is a weaver who came to Australia from Latvia. In this film she talks about both her own design work and the traditional Latvian weaving that she does.

results.title: Lilian's story [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Marian MacGowan, CML Film and Jerzy Domaradzki
results.brief_description: Forty years after Lillian Singer had been locked up in a mental institution by her father, she begins a new life. Equipped with a room of her own, an allowance, a strong sense of destiny and the words of Shakespeare, she sets out to live her new life on the streets, buses and taxis of Sydney. This is the extraordinary tale of one woman’s struggle to be free from her past and reclaim the love that was denied her. For Lillian it is never too late to change or discover happiness. Life, for her, is an experience where “everything matters”. Starring Ruth Cracknell and Toni Collette. Adapted from the novel by Kate Grenville. In widescreen format.

results.title: Lilacs in the spring
results.brief_description: Based upon the stage production of Robert Nesbitt’s “The Glorious days” by Harold Purcell with original music by Harry Parr Davies. This is a song and dance romantic comedy set in London during WWII starring the ever-charming somewhat older Errol Flynn, along with Anna Neagle, David Farrar, Kathleen Harrison, Peter Graves and Helen Haye.

results.title: Like you, like me: see what I feel
results.creator_credit: Alan P. Sloan and Encyclopaedia Britannica Educational Corporation
results.brief_description: An animated film which dramatises how a child copes with blindness. Designed to encourage discussion of attitudes toward the blind and to show that a blind or visually impaired child can do many things that other children do.

results.title: Like water for chocolate = Como agua para chocolate
results.creator_credit: Arau Films International and Alfonso Arau
results.brief_description: Multi-award winning Mexican film which tells the story of Tita who is forbidden by tradition and a tyrannical mother to marry Pedro. Tita finds solace for her suppressed passion and sorrow in her cooking, which has a profound effect on all who partake. Based on Laura Esquivel’s best-seller, “Like water for chocolate” is an enchanting film which radiates warmth and emotional depth. It is visual feast starring Marco Leonardi, Lumi Cavazos and Regina Torne. Spanish dialogue. English subtitles.

results.title: Like two mountaineers: the development of Cubism
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre and Ross Campbell
results.brief_description: Using examples from the Modern Masters exhibition, this film traces the early influences of Suerat, Cezanne and African art on the development of Cubism. Paintings of Picasso and Braque are shown in great detail from the period when they worked “like two mounaineers roped together”. No commentary, music soundtrack only. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Like they used to
results.brief_description: A short story about a Kensington cobbler’s shop that sends a message about our increasingly disposable consumer culture. Made as part of the ‘Pride and Diversity’ workshop in association with Vic Health.
